Geometry of Vector Bundles and Connections

1. Introduction

In this note we investigate and introduce important geometric tools for studying vector bundles on manifolds, including connections, orientations, the Poincaré-Hopf Theorem, Holonomy, and their relation with cohomology classes. These notes primarily follow lectures by Rui Fernandes in the Spring of 2025 at UIUC.

1.1. Preliminaries

To begin we recall, and internalize, the classification of vector bundles via cocycles. Recall that for a topological space with an open cover and a topological group, a -valued cocycle is a family of continuous (smooth) maps such that

Note that given the first two conditions, the cocycle condition is equivalent to a functoriality condition, namely that . Two such cocycles on the same cover are said to be equivalent if we have a family of continuous (smooth) maps such that

More generally we say two cocycles on are equivalent if there is some common refinement of their covers on which they are equivalent.

Metrics on Vector Bundles

We begin by considering Riemannian metrics on vector bundles.

Riemannian Metric

A (smooth) Riemannian metric on a (smooth) vector bundle is a continuous (resp. smooth) map such that defines an inner product on .

Equivalently, a Riemannian metric is a section of that is fiberwise positive definite.

If for a smooth manifold, then this recovers the notion of orientation for . We can re-express the orientability condition for a vector bundle by saying that there exists a cover of by local trivializations with cocycles that factor through the subgroup of positive determinant matrices.

Proof.

3. Connections on Vector Bundles

We now discuss the theory of connections on vector bundles, together with their interaction in geometry through curvature tensors.

Linear Connection

A linear connection on a vector bundle is a map
satisfying

  1. is -bilinear;

When , this recovers the notion of affine connection on the smooth manifold . As in this special case, connections on a vector bundle form an affine space modelled on the vector space of bundle morphisms . Indeed, if and are two connections, then corresponds to a -bilinear map , or equivalently a -linear map , which is the same as a bundle morphism . Additionally, under this correspondence, if is a connection and is some -bilinear map, so that it corresponds to a bundle morphism, the sum is again a connection.

Alternatively, a bundle morphism can also be thought of as a smooth family of -linear maps , which is the same as a -form in . Thus, we can also think of the space of linear connections on as an affine space modelled on .
